awd_titl_txt: GP-IMPACT: ICE-AGE: Integrating Continuous Experiential Activities for Geoscience Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
Recruiting undergraduate students to geoscience majors in
Tennessee is severely hampered by the fact that most Tennessee high schools do not offer
a geoscience class. As a result, students tend to graduate high school and enter college
with no real idea that geoscience is a potential major. Project ICE-AGE will engage with
high school students by exposing them to the geosciences in the context of core science
classes. First, a series of "Lessons-In-A-Box" will be designed to meet state
educational standards in the core sciences of biology, chemistry, and physics, but drawn
explicitly from interdisciplinary geoscience fields. These lessons will be tested with
visiting school groups at a campus museum, introduced to area teachers through
workshops and educational conferences, and circulated by the Knox County Public
Library System. Second, the PIs will collaborate with three groups of high school students,
including two that consist primarily of underrepresented minorities, on authentic
scientific research. This work expands a project with one high school that has resulted in
participation of students in writing a peer-reviewed paper, and four student-led
presentations at regional and national scientific meetings. Finally, PIs will create two new
classes for future teachers in culturally responsive geoscience education and research
methods in science. Taken together, PIs expect to introduce area high school students and
future teachers to the geosciences in such a way as to enhance their required learning
objectives and expose them to the potential for further study and employment in geology
and related fields.

Part 2
The project proposes to develop and deploy an integrated set of
programs that will engage high school students along a spectrum from one-day lessons
that will contact large numbers of students, to intensive, year-long research projects that
will involve a smaller number of students. PIs will also train pre-service STEM teachers
in the use of active learning techniques using geological concepts. PIs will specifically
work with high school populations that are enriched in underrepresented minorities, in
order to address the low diversity of current geoscience students and practitioners. PIs
will actively promote these programs to teachers around the country via teachers'
workshops, STEM education conferences, and professional geoscience conferences.
Finally, this project will produce scholarship in the fields of education and geoscience.
PIs expect that these efforts will expose ~165 high school students to authentic
geoscience research and at least 1000 students to Lessons-In-A-Box. The project will also help to
train ~90 pre-service teachers, 6 graduate students, and 1 undergraduate in teaching
geoscience and generating culturally responsive lesson plans. This project will also lead
to closer collaboration between faculty in the University of Tennessee's Departments of
Theory and Practice in Teacher Education, and Earth and Planetary Sciences. In the long
term these collaborations will help EPS faculty to improve teaching techniques for
undergraduates and to train more pre-service teachers in geoscience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on experiential geoscience learning for K-12 students in Tennessee, a state in which Earth Science education is not explicitly part of the high school curriculum. The project consisted of two prongs: a high-reach, lower intensity program to create geoscience “lessons in a box” that could be distributed to students via museums, libraries, and direct distribution to K-12 teachers, and a more intensive geoscience learning experience based on facilitating authentic geoscience research with K-12 students. Although this project was modified substantially due to the onset of the pandemic, which coincided with the planned start of the project, the major goals of the project were accomplished, and we have submitted papers to peer-reviewed journals on each prong of the project.  

The first prong of the project resulted in two “lessons in a box”: a board game about climate change (Fig 1), and carbon cycle modeling kit with associated lesson plan (Fig 2). “Climate Change, The Board Game” has been shared with middle and high school teachers at state and national science teacher conferences, and is available for demonstration and distribution through informal education venues at natural history museums in Tennessee, Texas, and Colorado. The game has been incorporated into geology course at the University of Tennessee Knoxville and Washington University and reposited with “Easy as Play,” formerly known as “Biology in a Box.” Taken all together, this lesson kit is expected to be used with ~1,100 students annually, and we are continuing to distribute digital and physical copies of the game at request. The carbon cycle modeling lesson has been used in the same undergraduate geology course and has supported non-science majors in particular with concrete representations of carbon cycling and structure. The kits were designed to be scalable to different academic grades, making them accessible to a broader array of students. Notably, both kits fulfill next generation science standards for high school chemistry and biology courses, which are required in Tennessee, and general education science requirements at both participating universities. Additionally, a manuscript stemming from these lessons-in-a-box has been submitted for publication to potentially extend the exposure to secondary science teachers. It is currently under review.

The second prong of the project aimed to provide a more intensive geoscience learning experience to a smaller group of students via involvement in authentic research experiences. For three summers, PI Steen as well as graduate students and undergraduate students worked with students at East Tennessee Freedom School, a summer program for K-12 students. We combined authentic geoscience research with classroom instruction in domain topics (e.g., biogeochemistry, elemental cycles, etc) and information about the practice of science (e.g., how to formulate scientific questions and design experiments). Each year we experimented with topics that would be engaging to students, logistically feasible, and methodologically simple enough that students could meaningfully participate in the research. In 2021, 2022, and 2023, projects focused on microbial extracellular enzymes, air quality and the urban heat island effect, and environmental lead. The quality of the final research product improved over the course of the project, and culminated in students presenting their work in 2023 to a panel including local politicians and educational officials (Fig 3). A manuscript about this work has been accepted for publication pending minor revisions.

Collectively, this exposed many Tennessee K-12 students to geoscience using evidence-based, experiential learning techniques. We have presented the results of the project at educational and scientific conferences, and we are in the process of disseminating the results in the peer-reviewed literature.
